title: An Ontology Design Pattern for Spatial Data Quality Characterization in the Semantic Sensor Web

author: Auriol Degbelo, Institute for Geoinformatics, University of Münster

segmentation: Hi everyone, I'm Oriel developed from the Institute for Geoinformatics, other University of Minister and I'm currently doing my PhD studies within International Research Training Group on semantic integration of geospatial information.
I warmly work.
OK, I warmly welcome you to this talk.
And here is the out.
Flying I will start with the motivations, then give some words on spatial data quality.
Describe the pattern, its benefits and tradeoffs, and finish with shorts.
Sorry.
So the motivation it has started here also with the SSN ontology that was described by the W trees that was developed by the W 3C semantic sensor Network Incubator Group.
So the ontology describes concepts and relations really went to sensors.
And to increase reuse ability to group made it modular and was pointing out that other models should be developed to take into account specific needs from different users.
Next to this is a recent review of the OGC Semantic Web Enablement Initiative.
That has pointed out that knowledge about equality of sensor outputs is currently needed and is currently missing.

So taking these two things together, putting them together has led me to suggest a module that could be added on top of the semantic ontology to describe call quality of a sensor, outputs and then I have focused on spatial data quality aspects because.
The.
The semantic sensor web is built on top of standard that are developed by the Open Geospatial Consulting.
Now a question is what is quality and I have taken?
A consumer oriented perspective on the term and adopted the definition.

The degree to which a data or service for fears they need of a consumer and when looking at the literature on spatial data quality, have observed that spatial data quality components vary from author to also at least would include, for example, completeness, logical consistency, positional accuracy.
Temporal accuracy attribute accuracy.
Another list would include, for example, increasing resolution, consistency, and image and deferred.
This would include accuracy, resolution, consistency, completeness, and.
That is not the end of it.
There could be more listed here.
So these things and this variation.
So just two things.
First of all, the final consumer should be given the choice to decide what to include in his or her list of special data quality components.
And the second thing is that most of the concepts listed here.
Are not directly measurable.
For example, if you take accuracy, it is defined as the closeness of a value to the truth.
That is a perfect observation.
And since there is no way to get this perfect observation, what is done is.
You take the value you have and you compare with a value that is considered to be of higher accuracy.
So this thing has been a motivation for me to add this second part of the definition that it is a function of intangible properties.
Intangible meaning here that.
We are proximate through some means, but we don't get exactly what the concept is so intense about properties of the data considered pertinent to the satisfaction of the consumers need.
So here is the pattern.
It has mainly 5 components.
You have data that is basically equivalent to the observation as defined in the SSN ontology.
Then you have a data quality component that is any property of the data that the consumer would like to approximate would have the data quality criterion that is.
The criteria that is used to assess the data quality.
Then you have the result and you have the.
Called the data quality observation that is used to link between the previous 4 ones.
So an example of of data will be raster image raster data and then an example of data quality component will be spatial resolution.
And an example of data quality criterion could be rather sell.

So it means I use the cell of my roster to assess the resolution of the data and a result would be 20 meters and the observation that links for the pattern has been aligned to the foundational ontology dulce ultralight as.
The SSN Ontology did before.

The benefits and tradeoffs of the pattern, so the benefits are inference of spatial data quality, component values and detection of inconsistency when different quality criteria are used for quality assessment.
And two.
To get bit an idea of this last point.
And take a small example.
That we have an observation collection and we would like to assess the quality of it and we assume we use.
We use the spacing of the different observation that is, the higher the spacing, the lower quality.
Now even for this.
A small property of spacing there could be two ways of looking at it.
You could look at it recently.
Are vertically and depending on whether you use the original or the vertical one you will get.
Different results, so the pattern would help to account for such cases because the data quality criterion would be made then explicit.
And.
The trade off of the pattern are it does not help too.

To get to the state where we can say immediately a high quality or low quality what it helps to do is to infer the value of spatial data quality components and then the user would have at the end to decide whether, for example, the.
Statement resolution equals 20 meters means for him or high or low quality.
Yeah, getting slowly to the end.
So here is a summary of the main ideas presented.

I've taken a consumers view on data quality and suggested a pattern with five elements data that is observation as the SSN ontology has described before and then they talk quality component property of the data that the user would like to approximate.
Then you have a data quality criterion criterion that is used to.

In a data quality assessment inspiration, you have the final result and you have a data quality observation that links the previous four and the usefulness is that it is a complementing module to the SSN ontology dealing with quality aspects and it is relevant for inference of spatial data quality component values and for efforts on semantic integration of.
Datasets.
The refresh I've used while preparing these slides.
And thank you very much for your.
Nations.
Your questions are welcomed.
